title: Bringing collocation prompts to text editors
segmentation: I must say I'm a little bit embarrassed because I come from a country with 200 million speakers of Portuguese and we don't have a decent collocation dictionary and you are only 2 million and you really have such impressive tools for such a small language, so congratulations on that.

I'm based now at the University of Surrey in the UK and I just put the little symbol of the European Union here so that you are very clear about my position in relation to what's going to happen or not next year.
For those of you who don't know where the University of Surrey is, we're in the English countryside.
But we're also very near London in a little town called Guilford, OK.
And I'll start with an overview of dictionaries.
I'll go through very, very quickly, but as you, most of you probably know in this audience, dictionaries in the past were mostly just a language inventory.
And the focus was on word meaning and maybe spelling standardization.
And a little bit about the origin of words, and it was really up to the users to decipher much of the contents of dictionaries in the past.
Things began to change in the middle of last century when users began to be taken into account.
Who uses dictionaries?

So there were the first dictionaries for learners where lexicographers started thinking about, well, what words should we include in the dictionaries, you know, very rare words are probably not so important for learners.
And then about a defining vocabulary, what word shall we use to define the words in the dictionary?
They can't be more complicated than the words we're looking at themselves.
Otherwise it's just all very circular.
And usage labels.
Let's give users some information about whether a word is formal, informal, ironic, humorous, and so on.
And usage patterns.
Let's also give users some cues about syntactic patterns.
What prepositions follow this verb, or what adjectives go with this noun and a little bit about pronunciation.
Let's help users say the words that they find in dictionaries.
Next big paradigm, the corpus revolution.
I was an MA student in applied linguistics in Edinburgh when John Sinclair came with the 1st edition of the Collins Cobuild English language Dictionary.
The first ever dictionary made with corpus data.
And I thought maybe when they are working this and here I am.
So huge amounts of empirical data about how people really use the language.
Dictionaries began to be take word frequency into account, not just lexicographers intuitions about what words are important to include, but also how language is really used.
Information on collocation on which words go well together on phraseology.
An above all authentic examples about how people really use the language.
With this new start, new dictionaries began to be created.
So you have, for English at least, lots of collocation dictionaries.
Now all corpus based here.
Next paradigm, the electronic medium.
Dictionaries are all of a sudden free from the alphabetical order.
You don't need that anymore to look up a word you don't even need to spell a word correctly 'cause there are spelling cues.
If you give an approximate spelling, you can also look up inflected forms and you will find the word you need, not just the base form of a word.
And you don't need to learn the phonetic alphabet.
You can just click on a button to hear the word being pronounced.
And there are enhanced visuals as well, color, even sometimes pictures.
And of course, more space when you're free from the paper you have more space for more content.
The content can be unpacked and everything becomes more readable.
And some dictionaries have started to add additional resources like exercises and great games and so on.
Next, paradigm portability you can access dictionaries from anywhere now.
And you can update dictionaries very regularly now.

And you can see what your users are doing with your dictionaries and they can communicate with you and suggest new words and you can track user logs to find out what's missing or what's wrong with your dictionaries.
And yet all these particular developments haven't had a very big impact on how people actually use dictionaries.
Today, both paper based.
If anyone still using them and digital dictionaries are still by and large underused.

Will still use dictionaries mainly to look at meanings, sometimes spellings, although this is being replaced by spellcheckers.
And above all translations.
Bilingual dictionaries are still very much in use.
But also people use dictionaries when they're engendering in games, like crosswords.
Or as an authority.
When people disagree about something, they use a dictionary to check who's right.
But language users in general are not fully aware of what else current dictionaries can offer them.
I did an experiment back in Lisbon with my students and most users didn't know that they could use dictionaries to look up collocations.

summarization_data.sent: I must say I'm a little bit embarrassed because I come from a country with 200 million speakers of Portuguese and we don't have a decent collocation dictionary and you are only 2 million and you really have such impressive tools for such a small language, so congratulations on that.

I'm based now at the University of Surrey in the UK and I just put the little symbol of the European Union here so that you are very clear about my position in relation to what's going to happen or not next year.
For those of you who don't know where the University of Surrey is, we're in the English countryside.
But we're also very near London in a little town called Guilford, OK.
And I'll start with an overview of dictionaries.
I'll go through very, very quickly, but as you, most of you probably know in this audience, dictionaries in the past were mostly just a language inventory.
And the focus was on word meaning and maybe spelling standardization.
And a little bit about the origin of words, and it was really up to the users to decipher much of the contents of dictionaries in the past.
Things began to change in the middle of last century when users began to be taken into account.
Who uses dictionaries?

So there were the first dictionaries for learners where lexicographers started thinking about, well, what words should we include in the dictionaries, you know, very rare words are probably not so important for learners.
And then about a defining vocabulary, what word shall we use to define the words in the dictionary?
They can't be more complicated than the words we're looking at themselves.
Otherwise it's just all very circular.
And usage labels.
Let's give users some information about whether a word is formal, informal, ironic, humorous, and so on.
And usage patterns.
Let's also give users some cues about syntactic patterns.
What prepositions follow this verb, or what adjectives go with this noun and a little bit about pronunciation.
Let's help users say the words that they find in dictionaries.
Next big paradigm, the corpus revolution.
I was an MA student in applied linguistics in Edinburgh when John Sinclair came with the 1st edition of the Collins Cobuild English language Dictionary.
The first ever dictionary made with corpus data.
And I thought maybe when they are working this and here I am.
So huge amounts of empirical data about how people really use the language.
Dictionaries began to be take word frequency into account, not just lexicographers intuitions about what words are important to include, but also how language is really used.
Information on collocation on which words go well together on phraseology.
An above all authentic examples about how people really use the language.
With this new start, new dictionaries began to be created.
So you have, for English at least, lots of collocation dictionaries.
Now all corpus based here.
Next paradigm, the electronic medium.
Dictionaries are all of a sudden free from the alphabetical order.
You don't need that anymore to look up a word you don't even need to spell a word correctly 'cause there are spelling cues.
If you give an approximate spelling, you can also look up inflected forms and you will find the word you need, not just the base form of a word.
And you don't need to learn the phonetic alphabet.
You can just click on a button to hear the word being pronounced.
And there are enhanced visuals as well, color, even sometimes pictures.
And of course, more space when you're free from the paper you have more space for more content.
The content can be unpacked and everything becomes more readable.
And some dictionaries have started to add additional resources like exercises and great games and so on.
Next, paradigm portability you can access dictionaries from anywhere now.
And you can update dictionaries very regularly now.

My students in Portugal.
